fields.System.Title: 2 - Assemble Team - Key roles in a IoT Solution Implementation
fields.System.Description:
Key roles in a IoT project include:

  • Business owner
  • Project manager (with agile methodology experience e.g. scrum)
  • Project coordinator
  • Cloud engineer (Infrastructure focused)
  • IoT Developer
  • Data virtualization specialist
  • Testing engineer
  • Business analysts (to help test BI tool queries, reports and analyses

fields.System.Title: Solution Scenario : Predictive Maintenance for Industrial IoT
fields.System.Description:
Imagine if you could predict equipment failures before they happen, and systematically prevent them. That’s what predictive maintenance offers. It involves using data to identify warning signs of potential problems, predict when equipment needs maintenance and preemptively service that equipment before problems occur.

his example scenario demonstrates how end manufacturers can connect assets to the cloud using OPC UA (Open Platform Communication Unified Architecture) and the Industrial Components. This will enable the use of Predictive Maintenance to improve the efficiency of your machines, while reducing the costs by optimizing the production.


Please review details here

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: Solution Scenario : Condition Monitoring for Industrial IoT
fields.System.Description:
Each remote monitoring project will be unique—tailored to the needs of your business and your equipment. But at its core, the principles and considerations for a remote monitoring solution are very similar. In the next sections of this document, you will see details you should consider when getting started on a remote monitoring project

This example scenario demonstrates how end manufacturers can connect their assets to the cloud using OPC UA (Open Platform Communication Unified Architecture) and the Industrial Components. They can monitor their equipment's key parameters to discover anomalies before they become critical issues

Please review this details

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: Solution Scenario : Process real-time vehicle data using IoT
fields.System.Description:
Vehicle data ingestion, processing, and visualization are key capabilities needed to create connected car solutions. By capturing and analyzing this data, we can decipher valuable insights and create new solutions.

Please review these details

fields.System.Title: Solution Scenario : IoT analytics
fields.System.Description:
This architecture pattern demonstrates near real-time analytics over fast flowing, high volume streaming data from IoT devices, sensors, connected buildings and vehicles, and so on. It focuses on integration of Azure Data Explorer with other IoT services to cater to both operational and analytical workloads using Cosmos DB and Azure Data Explorer.

Please review these details

fields.System.Title: Solution Scenario: Using Microsoft Azure IoT Solution Accelerators
fields.System.Description:
A cloud-based IoT solution typically uses custom code and cloud services to manage device connectivity, data processing and analytics, and presentation.

The IoT solution accelerators are complete, ready-to-deploy IoT solutions that implement common IoT scenarios. The scenarios include connected factory and device simulation. When you deploy a solution accelerator, the deployment includes all the required cloud-based services along with any required application code.


Please review this guidance

Refer to below solution accelerators
Connected Factory
Device Simulation

fields.System.Title: 3 - Deploy Azure IoT Edge
fields.System.Description:
Azure IoT Edge allows remote management of the code on our devices , enabling  us to send more workloads to the edge. Workloads can be deployed as modules on the Azure IoT Edge runtime , running on the devices. Modules can be custom built or can be from Azure Marketplace. Following resources provides guidance on how to develop & deploy IoT edge devices.

Quickstart create an Azure IoT Edge device on Linux | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial - Develop module for Linux devices using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: 2 - Deploy IoT Edge modules
fields.System.Description:
Workloads can be deployed to Azure IoT Edge runtime, running on the devices as IoT Edge modules. Modules can be custom built or can be from Azure Marketplace. These IoT Edge modules can connect with other Azure services and contribute to your larger cloud data pipeline. To deploy your program on an IoT Edge device, it must first be containerized and run with a Docker-compatible engine

Tutorial - Stream Analytics at the edge using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial - Store data with SQL module using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial - Deploy Custom Vision classifier to a device using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial - Deploy Azure Machine Learning to a device using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: 1 - Developing & deploying analytics to the Edge
fields.System.Description:
Analytics at the Edge

Enabling Analytics on the “Edge” devices provides various advantages.

It will minimize the amount of data that is sent to cloud over network and hence reduces cost.

Rather than processing data in the cloud, IoT Edge processes it on the device itself. It uses a field-programmable gate array (FPGA) to make real-time AI calculations, giving us the immediate insights, we need to make critical business decisions.

Operate edge devices reliably and securely, even when they are offline, or they have intermittent connectivity to the cloud

Azure Stream Analytics on IoT Edge enables deployment of near real-time analytical intelligence closer to IoT devices so that value of the device generated data can be unlocked in short span of time.

Analytical models can be trained in the cloud and run on edge devices.


Tutorial - Custom Python module tutorial using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial develop Node.js module for Linux - Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial - Custom Java module tutorial using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial develop C module for Linux - Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs
Tutorial - Develop C# module for Linux using Azure IoT Edge | Microsoft Docs


Analytics in the Cloud from Edge data:
Sync data from Azure SQL Edge by using Azure Data Factory | Microsoft Docs
Sync data from Azure SQL Edge by using SQL Data Sync | Microsoft Docs

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: 2 - Visualizing & acting on analytics
fields.System.Description:
Real-Time Analytics capability enables various use case scenarios where data can be consumed continuously, and actions can be triggered as immediate response.  Basic real-time dashboards can be enabled with the OOB configuration of Azure IoT Hub and PowerBI. Azure IoT Hub provides the flexibility to extend the OOB feature with custom coding to address various real-time analytical requirements. Azure Machine Learning can be used along with Azure IoT Hub to enable real-time predictive analytical scenarios like anomaly detection.

Real-time data visualization of data from Azure IoT Hub – Power BI | Microsoft Docs

fields.System.Description:

Device Simulation:

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: 1 - Configure Customization & gather insights
fields.System.Description:
Connected Factory:
Configure the Connected Factory topology - Azure | Microsoft Docs
Customize how the Connected Factory solution displays data from your OPC UA servers - Azure | Microsoft Docs

Device Simulation:
Modify simulated device code as needed for your scenario. Common scenarios:
  • Load Testing – Customers will be able to perform large scale tests using Device Simulation. Individual simulations will support up to 20,000 simulated devices.
  • IoT Demos – Device Simulation now includes sample simulations that can be started with a click. This allows for instant demos highlighting device data flowing to an IoT Hub.
  • Simple POCs – This scenario was supported in the initial release of Device Simulation. However, there are more capabilities here. Customers can create device models and re-use them for easily repeatable simulations. Individual simulations can also now support a mix of multiple device types.
  • Advanced device behaviors – Customers will be able to write custom JSON device definition files and script device behaviors using JavaScript. This allows for complex scenarios allowing a device to mimic the behavior of the real thing (e.g. vehicles following roads, interior temperature varying based on exterior temperature, etc.)
  • Simulation-driven development – Customers can use Device Simulation to generate both expected and unexpected telemetry for continuous testing while developing their solution on top of Azure IoT.

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: 1 - Deploy Azure Services on IoT Edge
fields.System.Description:
Deploying various Azure Services on IoT Edge 

Capabilities of the various Azure services can be leveraged on Azure IoT Edge runtime. These modules can work with Azure Blob storage. Azure Notebooks can be used to develop & deploy machine learning modules to perform predictive analytics on devices. Data can be stored in edge devices using Azure SQL Edge, which is a RDBMS engine optimized for Azure IoT edge devices. Code blocks implementing business logic can be deployed to the edge devices using Azure Functions. For any telemetry stream processing, we can move Azure Stream Analytics logic to edge devices, which helps in reducing amount of data that is uploaded to cloud & time required for actionable insights. Following resources provides guidance on extending these various Azure services to Azure IoT edge devices

Azure Blob Storage

Azure Machine Learning

Azure SQL Edge

Azure Functions

Azure Stream Analytics

attributes.comment: Making a new link for the dependency
attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Title: 1 - AML solution on IoT Edge
fields.System.Description:
Capability to deploy machine learning algorithms on the edge devices enables predictive analytics on the devices; Data no need to be transmitted to cloud for predictive analytics; Situations can be predicted upfront in the edge devices near to the field and actions can be triggered immediately.

Azure IoT Edge Runtime enables deployment of various workloads in the form of modules; Trained machine learning module can be deployed to edge using a container.

In this resource, we will see an end-to-end machine learning solution on IoT edge

Machine Learning on the Edge

fields.System.Title: 3 - Create serving layer to store data
fields.System.Description: Different databases are used depending on the data. Azure Cosmos DB stores the messages, while Azure SQL DB stores relational and transactional data, and acts as a data source for the presentation and action layer. Azure Synapse contains aggregated data and acts as the data source for Business Intelligence (BI) tools.

fields.System.Description:
The discovery module supports network scanning which will be used to find all OPC UA assets


Note: You must put correct I/P address (CIDR) format in the engineering tool. The address range is the IP range of the Azure VNet one where your simulation serves are located. In the real-world scenarios, it should map to the on-premises network (peered with Azure VNet through S2S VPN or Express route)

fields.System.Title: 6 - Publish data from your Assets
fields.System.Description:
To publish data the platform makes use the deployed OPC Publisher modules. The OPC Publisher module receives publish instructions (“jobs”) and executes these long running jobs. A publish job specifies the server and its nodes (Variables/events) that should be monitored and whose samples should be sent to Azure IoT Hub.

Please review this guidance

fields.System.Title: 3 - Review or Implement Rules Engine
fields.System.Description:
For a Rules Engine, a custom web application can be developed that allows users to author alerts and actions. The web application creates associated Jobs in Azure Stream Analytics using the Steam Analytics REST API. To trigger actions, a Stream Analytics Job calls an Azure Function output. The Azure Function can call a Logic App or Power Automate task that sends an Email alert or invokes Azure SignalR to display a message in the web application.

To display visual alerts in your web application, we recommend creating an Azure Stream Analytics job to detect specific events and send those to either:

  • An Event Hub output - Then connect the Event Hub to Time Series Insights. Use the Azure Time Series Insights JavaScript SDK (tsiclient) to display the event in your web application.

or,

  • An Azure Functions output - Then develop an Azure Function that sends the events to your web application using SignalR.
Please review this guidance

attributes.name: Parent

fields.System.Description:
To publish data the platform makes use the deployed OPC Publisher modules. The OPC Publisher module receives publish instructions (“jobs”) and executes these long running jobs. A publish job specifies the server and its nodes (Variables/events) that should be monitored and whose samples should be sent to Azure IoT Hub.

fields.System.Title: 1 - Discover your assets
fields.System.Description:
The discovery module supports network scanning which will be used to find all OPC UA assets


Note: You must put correct I/P address (CIDR) format in the engineering tool. The address range is the IP range of the Azure VNet one where your simulation serves are located. In the real-world scenarios, it should map to the on-premises network (peered with Azure VNet through S2S VPN or Express route)
